WASHINGTON U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan said on Thursday he is not ready to support or endorse Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump.""I'm just not ready to do that at this point. I'm not there right now
column2: Ryan
column3: a Republican
column4: said in an interview with CNN.

column1: Ryan
column2: who added he hoped to support Trump's candidacy
column3: was making his first public comments since Trump's Republican primary rivals dropped out of the race for the White House this week.

column1: (Reporting by Mohammad Zargham and Susan Cornwell; Writing by Eric Walsh; Editing by James Dalgleish)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-reid-idUSKCN0XW1ZT	Not over yet: Reid cautions Democrats relishing Trump election battle	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON For some Democrats
column2: Donald Trump may seem to be a gift - set to steer Republicans into a trainwreck election in November - but senior Democrat Harry Reid said on Thursday he worried people might be too confident. ""Am I concerned about it? Of course I am
column3: the U.S. Senate Democratic leader said in a conference call with reporters. ""I think this race could be a debacle for the Republicans
column4: Reid added. ""But I'm not taking anything for granted. I'm not being over confident.""Trump effectively clinched the Republican presidential nomination for the Nov. 8 election this week after a primary battle that angered many - including in his own party's establishment - for his bombastic style and proposals such as building a wall along the southern U.S. border to keep out Mexicans.

column1: Some Democrats believe that divisive style makes him an easier opponent than some of the other 16 Republicans who started out in the race. Trump's Democratic opponent will likely be former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.Reid
column2: who is retiring from the Senate after this year
column3: used his position as the Senate's Democratic leader in 2012 to aggressively attack then-Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney.

column1: During a teleconference to discuss Trump and Republican opposition to Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland
column2: Reid made clear that he will perform in a similar role against Trump.""By nominating Trump
column3: I guess it's the natural evolution of a party that's spent eight years defining itself entirely on what it's against: anti-immigrant
column4: anti-woman
column5: ...anti-Obama

column1: Reid
column2: who has called Trump a ""monster
column3: said there should be a closer look at Trump's business dealings and called on the real estate developer to open up his tax records.Reid recalled some of his own campaigns in his political career that were lost or won by razor-thin margins
column4: adding
column5: ""I can speak from personal experience. You cannot be over-confident."" (Reporting By Richard Cowan; Editing by Dan Grebler and Frances Kerry)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN0XV2CT	Clinton calls Trump a 'loose cannon
column2: ' risky choice for president	"

column1: WASHINGTON U.S. Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton took quick aim at presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump on Wednesday
column2: saying the United States should not take a risk on an unreliable candidate.""He is a loose cannon
column3: and loose cannons tend to misfire
column4: Clinton said in an interview with CNN
column5: citing Trump stances including an allegation that climate change was a Chinese hoax. Clinton
column7: said Trump would have to offer policy specifics in ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election and criticized him for his positions on issues including nuclear weapons and abortion.""He makes these grand statements and grand accusations
column8: Clinton said of the real estate magnate and former reality TV star. ""At some point when you're running for president
column9: you actually have to put a little meat on the bones. You've got to tell people what it is you're going to do and how you're going to do it.""Clinton lost the Democratic primary contest in Indiana on Tuesday but still looks set to win her party's nomination
column12: by more than 800 delegates. Trump's win in Indiana on Tuesday pushed his rivals out of the race and left him as the presumptive nominee.In a preview of the likely general election battle
column13: Clinton laughed when asked if she was ready to take on Trump

column1: This is to me a classic case of a blustering
column2: bullying guy who has knocked out of the way all the Republicans because they were just dumbfounded
column3: she said.Clinton said she knew how to run a campaign against Trump and took a swipe at Trump's 16 Republican presidential rivals who started out in the 2016 campaign.

column1: They didn't know how to deal with him
column2: Clinton said. ""They couldn't take him on the issues because they basically agreed with them. And they didn't know how to counterpunch.""Asked how ""scorched-earth"" the campaign was likely to be
column3: she replied: ""You know
column4: he's the one making that decision. ... He's the one who's run the campaign insulting people
column5: demeaning women
column7: talking about keeping Muslims out of the country
column8: he's the one that's been running that kind of very negative
column10: bullying campaign.""I'm going to keep staying on the kind of campaign I'm running

column1: (Reporting by Megan Cassella and Doina Chiacu; Additional reporting by Tim Ahmann and Eric Walsh; Editing by Frances Kerry and Peter Cooney)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-trade-tpp-whitehouse-idUSKCN0XW1Y3	White House says Congress has no reason to wait until after Nov election to take up TPP	"

WASHINGTON The White House on Thursday said that it sees no reason to wait until after the Nov. 8 presidential election for Congress to take up discussions on the Trans-Pacific Partnership""There's no reason we need to wait that long
column2: particularly when you consider that ratifying the Trans-Pacific Partnership would hasten the end to 18
column3: 000 taxes that other countries impose on American goods
column4: White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters at the daily briefing.

column1: (Reporting by Jeff Mason; Writing by Alana Wise; Editing by Chris Reese)"
4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-mnuchin-idUSKCN0XW1LY	Republican Trump's new finance chair previously donated to Democrats	"
By Ginger Gibson and Grant Smith
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican Donald Trump named a national finance chairman for his presidential campaign on Thursday
column2: picking an investor with little experience in campaigns but a long history of political donations
column3: including to Trump's likely Democratic opponent
column4: Hillary Clinton.Steven Mnuchin
column5: a former partner at Goldman Sachs who now works in entertainment financing
column6: is chairman and CEO of private investment firm Dune Capital Management LP. He is taking one of the first high-profile jobs in the campaign that Trump has filled.Trump
column7: a real estate developer who this week became the presumptive Republican presidential nominee for the November election
column8: worked with Mnuchin in a business capacity before
column11: 000 to Democrats and their associated committees
column13: 000 to Republicans. Since Hillary Clinton's campaign to be elected to the U.S. Senate in 2000
column16: according to the Federal Election Commission. He also gave $10
column17: 000 to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in 2004.

column1: More recently
column2: Mnuchin donated to Republicans
column3: including $22
column4: 500 in 2012 to Mitt Romney's joint fundraising committee and another $4
column5: 800 to the former Republican nominee's campaign.His history of donations to Democrats may well add to distaste for Trump among some establishment Republicans who have opposed the billionaire's rise to likely presidential nominee on the grounds his proposals are not truly Republican.

column1: Trump said on Wednesday he will begin to raise money for his general election bid after self-funding a majority of his primary campaign. Fundraising will require a balance
column2: especially since much of Trump's campaign message has rested on his refusal to raise money and his decision to self-fund his campaign during the party nominating contests.Historically
column3: political parties have depended on the ability of their nominee to raise money in order to fund their other operations
column4: including working to elect members of the House and Senate. Trump said he will work closely with the Republican National Committee - which already has a fundraising operation - to help both his own campaign and those of other members of the party for the Nov. 8 election.

column1: U.S. Representative Chris Collins of New York
column2: who was the first lawmaker to endorse Trump
column3: said the move to start raising money will help bring the party together.""You'll see that pivot to the general election
column4: which is uniting the party
column5: and fundraising is a very big part of uniting the party
column6: with the influence money has in elections these days
column7: Collins told Reuters in an interview. (Reporting by Megan Cassella and Susan Cornwell; Editing by Dan Grebler and Frances Kerry)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-scotland-idUSKCN0XW1KY	Scottish isle a world away from fireworks of native son Trump	"
By Elisabeth O'Leary
| ISLE OF LEWIS
column2: Scotland

column1: ISLE OF LEWIS
column2: Scotland Donald Trump has played up his family roots from Lewis
column3: an island off the northwestern tip of Scotland
column4: but his success in the U.S. Republican presidential battle has not drawn the kind of rapture the billionaire might like from his home crowd.Trump's mother
column5: Mary Anne MacLeod
column6: emigrated to the United States from the Lewis village of Tong in the early 1930s
column7: and a visit from her property mogul son would certainly interest the friendly inhabitants of this weather-beaten isle. But the kind of fiery oratory that has catapulted him to unexpected victories in the U.S. primaries might be taken with a pinch of salt
column9: manager of the post office in the capital Stornoway.""People here like proof and anything less than that is suspect
column11: a 43-year-old American originally from Kentucky who has lived here for a decade. ""There would certainly be lots of talk about him after he left
column12: but the talk would be subdued and the laughter would be gentle."" The islanders' wariness is apparent when the New Yorker's name is mentioned; many smile politely and refuse to talk about him at all
column13: making it difficult to gauge sentiment among the 20
column14: 000-strong population. But even such silence is significant in a place of strong community ties
column15: according to critically-acclaimed Lewis novelist Kevin MacNeil. ""If people from Lewis were genuinely supportive of Trump they would be more vocal in their views
column16: he said. ""The lack of support for a grandson of the island speaks volumes.""An exception is a Facebook page called ""Isle of Lewis supports Trump for President"" which has 84 ""likes"".The businessman has become the presumptive Republican nominee with a headline-grabbing campaign in which he has traded insults with rivals. A suggestion Muslims should be banned from entering the United States drew criticism from Europe and led to the withdrawal of Scottish business and academic accolades.Trump argued last month
column17: in a column in Aberdeen's Press and Journal newspaper
column18: that he had won over the skeptical people of Scotland through tenaciousness after he built his golf course despite environmental hurdles
column19: local opposition and lawsuits.""Scotland has already been won - and so will the United States

column1: Trump called his Scottish business project a ""labor of love"" and his Trump International Golf Links website has a section dedicated to his Scots' family genealogy. FREEZING GUSTS
It would be funny if Trump won. It might boost tourism
column2: said Donald
column3: a Lewis pensioner living near the MacLeod family seat.""But only for a while
column4: interjected his wife Anne
column5: with the caution habitual of the island.

column1: The couple recalled that Trump's mother would visit from the United States in the summer
column2: and Trump's millionaire father Fred would ship over a Cadillac to carry her around the marshy island during her stay.""You'd end up in the ditch if you were trying to drive past them
column3: I remember that
column4: said Donald with a laugh.Lewis
column5: in the Outer Hebrides island chain
column8: hills and open tracts of moor and almost devoid of trees. A freezing gust can whip your breath away or a warm breeze can surprise you with its gentleness. Trump stopped for a brief visit in 2008
column9: jetting in on his private plane when he was trying to launch a golf business near Aberdeen in mainland Scotland and holding a news conference. He has not returned since
column10: although he has visited Scotland several times and runs two golf courses on the mainland
column11: one in Ayrshire and another in Aberdeenshire.

column1: He was then offered the possibility of an investment in Lews (sic) Castle
column2: a run-down Victorian country house in Stornoway built by another millionaire
column3: Sir James Matheson
column4: when he bought the island in the mid-19th century.""He just didn't think he was going to make any money out of it. He knows his roots are here but he's more interested in his golf investments elsewhere
column5: said council official Nigel Scott.    People are not easily swayed in Lewis
column6: where strong bonds between neighbors and family are necessary to withstand the harshness of rural life
column7: said Calum Iain Macleod a Presbyterian minister from the parish where Mary Anne MacLeod was born.""When the Atlantic is throwing a force 10 and you can barely stand and your windows are caked with salt
column8: it is extreme and it is tough
column9: he said.""Being on this island where The Minch separates you from the center of gravity
column12: referring to a strait that separates the Outer Hebrides from the mainland.The influence of the Church itself
column14: also makes for a tranquil place. Sundays are still almost entirely commerce-free and pubs and hotels which serve alcohol are very few
column15: in contrast to the rest of Britain.Trump's desire to recall his historic Scottish roots may have another purpose
column16: suggests novelist MacNeil.""Perhaps he simply wants a Scotland-shaped mirror to reflect back his own perceived glory."" (Reporting By Elisabeth O'Leary; Editing by Estelle Shirbon and Pravin Char)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-autos-wireless-idUSKCN0XW1H9	Automakers
column2: states urge White House to reject plan to open spectrum	"

column1: By David Shepardson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON More than 50 automakers
column2: state transportation agencies and other groups urged the White House and other federal policymakers on Thursday not to open a portion of the wireless spectrum reserved for connected vehicles in the near future.The letter was signed by major auto trade groups representing nearly the entire auto industry
column3: including Toyota Motor Corp
column4: Ford Motor Co
column5: General Motors Co
column6: Volkswagen AG (VOWG_p.DE) and Honda Motor Co. It came a week after a cable industry trade group and some tech companies
column8: and public interest groups urged the White House to take quick action to open the spectrum to more wireless devices.Automakers and companies seeking to use the 5.9 GHz unlicensed spectrum band for wireless devices have been sparring for several years.In January
column9: U.S. Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx sent a proposed regulation to the White House that would require all new cars to be equipped with ""vehicle-to-vehicle"" technology that could eventually prevent up to 80 percent of crashes in which alcohol is not a factor. The proposal will not be final until approved by the White House and opened for public comment.The technology
column10: which involves cars repeatedly sending wireless signals to each other
column11: could help alert drivers if an oncoming vehicle may disregard a traffic light. It can detect threats from hundreds of yards away and indicate whether  vehicles can
column13: pass safely or make a left turn.

column1: One of the most - if not the most - significant advances in vehicle safety is now coming into existence. We urge you to stay the course and complete the action your administration has undertaken to improve the safety of drivers and passengers on America's roadways
column2: said the letter
column3: signed by the auto and auto parts trade groups as well as the Michigan
column4: California and Arizona state transportation departments and the National Safety Council and National Sheriffs Association.Automakers say vehicle-to-vehicle technology could also help speed self-driving cars to the roads.Last week in a separate letter to the Obama administration
column5: the National Cable and Telecommunications Association and other groups said the president needs to act quickly because as connected device use ""continues to skyrocket
column6: the spectrum resources that power our devices are perilously insufficient.""

column1: The groups urged speedy action. ""We must act now to find more unlicensed spectrum
column2: they wrote.Michael Calabrese
column3: director for wireless policy at New America's Open Technology Institute
column4: said the ""auto industry ignores the fact that their unused band has enough spectrum to deploy - and protect - both crash avoidance safety applications and next generation Wi-Fi.""Dave Sullivan
column5: an analyst at AutoPacific
column6: said automakers have a lot at stake and have made significant investments in the technology. ""It's imperative that this spectrum not be encroached on

column2: the Federal Communications Commission allocated 75 megahertz of spectrum in the 5.9 GHz band for highway safety. But critics say the technology has not progressed much beyond the testing phase.FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler
column3: U.S. Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker and Foxx agreed in January to conduct testing on whether the spectrum can be shared with wireless devices.The government officials said it is ""imperative to ensure the future automotive safety and efficiency of the traveling public"" that testing be completed before they make any decisions on sharing the spectrum. (Additional reporting by Bernie Woodall in Detroit Reporting by David Shepardson; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and Dan Grebler)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-technology-idUSKCN0XV2R1	U.S. tech firms urge presidential candidates to embrace trade
column2: high-tech visas	"

column1: By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Thirteen U.S. industry groups representing technology companies  Amazon.com Inc (AMZN.O)
column2: Uber Technologies Inc
column3: Apple Inc (AAPL.O)
column4: Facebook Inc (FB.O) and others are pushing for the next U.S. president to support the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal and to make it easier to hire high-tech workers from abroad
column5: according to a joint letter seen by Reuters.Ahead of the Republican and Democratic conventions in July
column6: the tech industry plans to issue on Wednesday an open letter charting a dozen policy recommendations for the candidates running in the Nov. 8 presidential election. The groups are not aligning themselves with either of the two major political parties.Backing for the TPP runs counter to positions taken by presumptive Republican candidate Donald Trump and Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton. Trump has made criticism of international trade agreements and a call for tougher immigration policies central themes of his campaign. In a Republican debate in March the billionaire real estate developer shied away from arguing against more H-1B visas for skilled foreign workers
column7: saying he was ""softening the position because we need to have talented people in this country.""Clinton has not said if she would try to renegotiate TPP
column8: which was signed in February but has not yet got congressional approval. She has said she supports expanding the number of visas for high-skilled workers.

column1: Silicon Valley has struggled to notch policy wins in recent years on its legislative priorities
column2: including immigration and patent reform
column3: though the tech industry has succeeded in strengthening net neutrality protections and curtailing some government surveillance programs.The coalition letter
column4: signed by groups including the Internet Association
column5: Telecommunications Industry Association and Information Technology Industry Council
column6: is the first time a wide range of technology trade organizations have staked out a common platform during a presidential campaign
column7: according to a person familiar with its writing.The platform also calls for ""narrowly targeted government access to user data"" and recognition of encryption as a ""critical security tool.""

column1: Trump has urged the restoration of the National Security Agency's (NSA) bulk collection of U.S. phone records
column2: saying that U.S. authorities should err on the side of protecting national security over privacy concerns.Trump also urged a boycott of Apple during the company's high-profile clash earlier this year with the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation over unlocking an encrypted iPhone linked to a San Bernardino
column3: California gunman.

column1: Clinton has supported some reforms to the NSA and has said a balance needs to be found between privacy and security in the encryption debate.The letter also calls for preventing censorship online by limiting unreasonable third-party liability for speech
column2: support for the sharing economy
column3: and an updated and simplified tax code
column4: among other issues.Signatories also include Allied for Startups
column5: BSA The Software Alliance
column12: Technology CEO Council and TechNet. (Reporting by Dustin Volz; Editing by Caren Bohan and Bill Rigby)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN0XW13G	Trump wants to help U.S. businesses by lifting slew of regulations: CNBC	"
WASHINGTON Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump outlined economic policy initiatives on Thursday that he would pursue if elected to the White House in November
column2: including refinancing longer-term U.S. debt
column3: lowering taxes and scrapping a slew of federal regulations.The Manhattan real estate mogul said his aim would be to clear the way for U.S. businesses to succeed.""We're lowering taxes very substantially and we're going to be getting rid of a tremendous amount of regulations
column4: Trump said in a wide-ranging interview with CNBC.""The business people they talk about regulation more than they talk about taxes

column6: U.S. Senator Ted Cruz and Ohio Governor John Kasich
column7: to drop out of the race.The candidate
column8: who has never held elective office
column9: has been pressed to provide more details on policy proposals. On Wednesday

column11: but that any increase would have to be weighed against a potential loss of competitiveness.

column4: including two of his Atlantic City casino companies

column1: I think there are times for us to refinance
column2: refinance debt with longer term
column3: he said. ""Because you know we owe so much money. Nobody talks about it - nobody talks about it until the bubble pops. And the bubble could pop
column4: and it could pop and it could be ugly.""Trump also warned about the downside of a strong U.S. dollar.""I love the concept of a strong dollar
column5: in many respects obviously I like a strong dollar. But when you look at the havoc that a strong dollar causes

column7: it sounds better to have a strong dollar than in actuality it is."" (Reporting by Doina Chiacu; Additional reporting by Megan Cassella; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and Frances Kerry)"
